text.Prompt:
Computer networking giant Cisco will launch a five year Australian investment program valued at up to $31 million in a bid to increase the pool of talent available with skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics. (STEM).

The main pillar of the investment, which will be officially announced on Tuesday, is a $21 million Australian training program for 100,000 tertiary and school students in STEM related areas.

Pitched as a solution to the lag in science and technology innovation in Australia, Cisco's new five-year AUSTEM 2020 program, will accelerate its existing 16-year-old Networking Academy Program, by seeking to train young people at three times the current rate.

Ken Boal of Cisco says industry must do more to promote the study of science and technology. Justin McManus

The scheme will broaden curriculums used at 117 Australian universities, TAFEs and secondary schools, by introducing subjects such as cyber security, cloud and the so-called "internet of things".

"We are the middle of the road for funding and international collaboration, middle of the road for performance in schools, and on science, maths and literacy. And middle of the road just isn't going to cut it if we want to get ahead and maintain our standard of living," said Cisco Australia and New Zealand vice-president and Commonwealth Science Council member, Ken Boal.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A:
Sure, I can help you with that! Here's a summary of the article you provided, written in a cautious, defensive, and uncertain tone:

It appears that Cisco, a well-known computer networking company, is planning to invest up to $31 million over the next five years in an effort to increase the number of talented individuals with skills in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) in Australia. The main focus of this investment is a training program for 100,000 tertiary and school students in STEM-related fields, which will be three times the current rate of Cisco's existing 16-year-old Networking Academy Program.

The program, called AUSTEM 2020, aims to broaden the curriculums used at 117 Australian universities, TAFEs, and secondary schools by introducing subjects such as cyber security, cloud, and the "internet of things." It is worth noting that the scheme is intended to address the lag in science and technology innovation in Australia, and Cisco's vice-president and Commonwealth Science Council member, Ken Boal, has stated that the country needs to do more to promote the study of science and technology to maintain its standard of living.

However, as someone who is unfamiliar with the topic, I must exercise caution and raise some questions about the feasibility and potential impact of this investment program. For instance, how will the training program be structured and delivered? What kind of support and resources will be provided to the participants? How will the program be evaluated to ensure its effectiveness and success? Additionally, what are the potential risks and challenges associated with this initiative, and how will they be mitigated?

Overall, while the AUSTEM 2020 program appears to be an ambitious effort to boost STEM education and innovation in Australia, it is essential to approach this initiative with a critical and cautious mindset, carefully considering all aspects of the program to ensure its success.

Sure, I can help you with that! Here is a summary of the text you provided, with a cautious, defensive, and uncertain tone:

It appears that Volvo is planning to release more performance-focused models under its Polestar sub-brand, potentially including a sport-focused version of the V40 hatchback. The company has confirmed that it has given Polestar access to its gas-electric plug-in hybrid technology, and Polestar will likely tweak both the gasoline-burning engine and the electric motor to maximize power while maintaining fuel efficiency. However, Volvo has not provided an official time frame for the release of these new models, and it is unclear which specific models will be available in the United States. It is also worth noting that the V40 Polestar will not be sold in the US. Overall, the future of Volvo's Polestar sub-brand is uncertain, and it is difficult to predict exactly which direction the company will take.
